column2: IPA: [vlədʲɪvɐˈstok] (listen)) is the largest city and the administrative centre of Primorsky Krai
column3: Russia. The city is located around the Golden Horn Bay on the Pacific Ocean
column4: covering an area of 331.16 square kilometres (127.86 square miles)
column5: with a population of 606
column6: 561 residents
column7: up to 812
column8: 319 residents in the urban agglomeration. Vladivostok is the second-largest city in the Far Eastern Federal District
column9: as well as the Russian Far East.

column1: The city was founded in 1860 as a Russian military outpost after the Treaty of Aigun and the Convention of Peking with the Qing dynasty. In 1872
column2: the main Russian naval base on the Pacific Ocean was transferred to the city
column3: and thereafter Vladivostok began to grow. After the outbreak of the Russian Revolution in 1917
column4: Vladivostok was occupied in 1918 by foreign troops
column5: the last of whom were not withdrawn until 1922
column6: by that time the anti-revolutionary White Army forces in Vladivostok promptly collapsed
column7: and Soviet power was established in the city. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union
column8: Vladivostok became the administrative centre of Primorsky Krai.

column1: Vladivostok is the largest Russian port on the Pacific Ocean
column2: and the chief economic
column3: scientific and cultural centre of the Russian Far East
column4: as well as an important tourism centre in Russia. As the terminus of the Trans-Siberian Railway
column5: the city was visited by over 3 million tourists in 2017. The city is the administrative centre of the Far Eastern Federal District
column6: and is the home to the headquarters of the Pacific Fleet of the Russian Navy. For its unique geographical location
column7: and its European culture
column8: the city is called "Europe in Asia". Many foreign consulates and businesses have offices in Vladivostok.

column2: or Ruler of the East. The name derives from Slavic "владь". "to rule" and Russian "восток"
column3: "east". (See the etymology of Vladimir (name).)

column1: It was first named in 1859 along with other features in the Peter the Great Gulf area by Nikolay Muravyov-Amursky.  The name was first applied to the bay but
column2: following an expedition by Alexey Shefner in 1860
column3: was later applied to the new settlement.On Chinese maps from the Yuan Dynasty (1271-1368)
column4: Vladivostok is called Yongmingcheng (永明城 [Yǒngmíngchéng]
column5: "city of eternal light"). Since the Qing dynasty
column6: the city is known as Haishenwai (海參崴
column7: Hǎishēnwǎi) in Chinese
column8: from the Manchu Haišenwai (Manchu: ᡥᠠᡳᡧᡝᠨᠸᡝᡳ; Möllendorff: Haišenwai; Abkai: Haixenwai) or "small seaside village".In China
column9: Vladivostok is now officially known by the transliteration 符拉迪沃斯托克 (Fúlādíwòsītuōkè)
column10: although the historical Chinese name 海参崴 (Hǎishēnwǎi) is still often used in common parlance and outside Mainland China to refer to the city. According to the provisions of the Chinese government
column11: all maps published in China have to bracket the city's Chinese name.The modern-day Japanese name of the city is transliterated as Urajiosutoku (ウラジオストク). Historically
column12: the city's name was transliterated with Kanji as 浦塩斯徳 and shortened to Urajio ウラジオ; 浦塩.

column2: the Russian government was looking for a stronghold in the Far East; this role was played in turn by the settlements of Okhotsk

column4: Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky
column5: and Nikolaevsk-on-Amur. By the middle of the 19th century
column6: the search for the outpost had reached a dead end: none of the ports met the necessary requirement: to have a convenient and protected harbor
column7: next to trade routes. The Aigun Treaty was concluded by the forces of the Governor-General of Eastern Siberia Nikolay Muravyov-Amursky
column8: an active exploration of the Amur region began
column9: and later
column10: as a result of the signing of the Treaty of Tientsin and the Convention of Peking
column11: the territory of modern Vladivostok were annexed to Russia. The very name Vladivostok appeared in the middle of 1859
column12: was used in newspaper articles and denoted a bay. On June 20
column13: (July 2) 1860 the transport of the Siberian Military Flotilla "Mandzhur" under the command of Lieutenant-Commander Alexei Karlovich Shefner delivered a military unit to the Golden Horn Bay to establish a military post
column14: which has now officially received the name of Vladivostok.

column2: the post officially received the status of a city. The 1890s saw a demographic and economic boom associated with the completion of the construction of the Ussuriyskaya branch of the Trans-Siberian Railway and the Chinese-Eastern Railway. According to the first census of the population of Russia on February 9
column3: 1897 roughly 29
column4: 000 inhabitants lived in Vladivostok
column5: and ten years later the city's population tripled.The first decade of the 20th century was characterized by a protracted crisis caused by the political situation: the government's attention was shifted to Port Arthur and the Port of Dalny. As well as the boxing uprising in North China in 1900–1901
column6: the Russo-Japanese War of 1904–1905
column7: and finally the first Russian revolution led to stagnation in the economic activity of Vladivostok.Since 1907
column8: a new stage in the development of the city began: the loss of Port Arthur and Dalny again made Vladivostok the main port of Russia on the Pacific Ocean. A free port regime was introduced
column9: and until 1914 the city experienced rapid growth
column10: becoming an important economic centre in the Asia-Pacific
column11: as well as an ethnically diverse city with a population exceeding over 100
column12: 000 inhabitants: during the time ethnic Russians made up less than half of the population
column13: and large Asian communities developed in the city. The public life of the city flourished; many public associations were created

column2: Revolution and Occupation ===
no active hostilities took place in the city. However
column3: Vladivostok was an important staging post for the import of military-technical equipment for troops from allied and neutral countries
column4: as well as raw materials and equipment for industry.Immediately after the October Revolution in 1917
column5: during which the Bolsheviks came to power
column6: the Decree on Peace was announced
column7: and as a result of the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk concluded between the Bolshevik government of Russia and the Central Powers
column8: led to the end of Soviet Russia's participation from World War I. On October 30
column9: the sailors of the Siberian Military Flotilla decided to "rally around the united power of the Soviets"
column11: as well as all of the Trans-Siberian Railway passed to the Bolsheviks. During the Russian Civil War
column13: they lost control of the city to the White Army-allied Czechoslovak Legion
column14: who declared the city to be an Allied protectorate. Vladivostok became the staging point for the Allies' Siberian intervention
column17: and China; China sent forces to protect the local Chinese community after appeals from Chinese merchants. The intervention ended in the wake of the collapse of the White Army and regime in 1919; all Allied forces except the Japanese withdrew by the end of 1920.

column1: Throughout 1919 the region was engulfed in a partisan war. To avoid a war with Japan
column2: with the filing of the Soviet leadership
column3: the Far Eastern Republic
column4: a Soviet-backed buffer state between the Soviet Russia and Japan
column5: was proclaimed on April 6
column6: 1920. The Soviet government officially recognized the new republic in May
column7: but in Primorye a riot occurred
column8: where significant forces of the White Movement were located
column9: leading to the creation of the Provisional Priamurye Government
column10: with Vladivostok as its capital.In October 1922
column11: the troops of the Red Army of the Far Eastern Republic under the command of Ieronim Uborevich occupied Vladivostok
column12: displacing the White Army formations from it. In November
column14: and became a part of Soviet Russia.

column1: By the time of the establishment of Soviet power
column2: Vladivostok was in decline: the retreating forces of the Japanese army removed all material values from the city. Life was paralyzed: there was no money in the banks
column3: the equipment of enterprises was plundered. Due to mass emigration and repression
column4: the city's population decreased to 106
column5: 000 inhabitants. During 1923 to 1925
column6: the government adopted a plan of the "three-year restoration"
column7: during which the commercial port was resumed
column8: which became the most profitable in the country in 1924 to 1925. The recovery period was distinguished by its peculiarities: the Russian Far East did not find war communism
column9: but immediately fell into the situation of the New Economic Policy.In 1925
column10: the government decides to accelerate the industrialization of the country. The first five-year plans changed the face of Primorye
column12: partly as a result of the creation of numerous concentration camps in the region. In the 1930s-1940s
column13: Vladivostok served as a transit point on the route of delivering prisoners and cargo for the Sevvostlag of the Soviet super-trust Dalstroy. The notorious Vladivostok transit camp was located in the city. In addition
column15: the Vladivostok forced labor camp (Vladlag) was located in the area of Vtoraya Rechka railway station.Vladivostok was not a place of hostilities during the Great Patriotic War
column16: although there was a constant threat of attack from Japan. In the city
column19: to which the residents of Vladivostok carried personal values. During the war years Vladivostok handled imported cargo (lend-lease) almost four times more than Murmansk and almost five times more than Arkhangelsk.

column1: By the decree of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union "Issues of the Fifth Navy" dated August 11
column3: a special regime was introduced in Vladivostok (it began to operate on January 1
column4: 1952); the city becomes closed to foreigners. It was planned to remove from Vladivostok not only foreign consulates
column5: but also the merchant and fish fleet and transfer all regional authorities to Voroshilov (now Ussuriysk). However
column6: these plans were not implemented.During the years of the Khrushchev Thaw
column7: Vladivostok received special attention from state authorities. For the first time
column8: Nikita Khrushchev visited the city in 1954 to finally decide whether to secure the status of a closed naval base for him. It was noted that at that time the urban infrastructure was in a deplorable state. In 1959
column9: Khrushchev visited the city again. The result is a decision on the accelerated development of the city
column10: which was formalized by the decree of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union on January 18
column12: a new tram line was built
column14: the city became a huge construction site: residential neighborhoods were being erected on the outskirts
column15: and new buildings for public and civil purposes were erected in the center.In 1974
column16: Gerald Ford paid an official visit to Vladivostok
column18: becoming the first President of the United States to visit the Soviet Union. Both sides signed the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty
column19: which helped to contain the nuclear arms race between the Soviet Union and the United States during the Cold War.On September 20
column21: Boris Yeltsin signed decree No. 123 "On the opening of Vladivostok for visiting by foreign citizens"
column22: which entered into force on January 1
column24: ceasing Vladivostok to be a closed city.

column2: Vladivostok hosted the 24th APEC summit. Leaders from the APEC member countries met at Russky Island
column3: off the coast of Vladivostok. With the summit on Russky Island
column4: the government and private businesses inaugurated resorts
column5: dinner and entertainment facilities
column6: in addition to the renovation and upgrading of Vladivostok International Airport. Two giant cable-stayed bridges were built in preparation for the summit
column7: the Zolotoy Rog bridge over the Zolotoy Rog Bay in the center of the city
column8: and the Russky Island Bridge from the mainland to Russky Island (the longest cable-stayed bridge in the world). The new campus of Far Eastern Federal University was completed on Russky Island in 2012.

column1: The city is located in the southern extremity of Muravyov-Amursky Peninsula
column2: which is about 30 kilometers (19 mi) long and 12 kilometers (7.5 mi) wide.

column1: The highest point is Mount Kholodilnik

column1: Located in the extreme southeast of the Russian Far East
column2: in the extreme southeast of North Asia. Vladivostok is geographically closer to Anchorage
column3: Alaska and even Darwin
column4: Australia than it is to the nation's capital of Moscow. Vladivostok is also closer to Honolulu
column5: Hawaii than to the city of Sochi in Southern Russia.

column1: Vladivostok has a monsoon-influenced humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dwb) with warm
column2: humid and rainy summers and cold
column3: dry winters. Owing to the influence of the Siberian High
column4: winters are far colder than a latitude of 43 °N should warrant given its low elevation and coastal location
column5: with a January average of −12.3 °C (9.9 °F). Since the maritime influence is strong in summer
column6: Vladivostok has a relatively cold annual climate for its latitude. Vladivostok's yearly mean of around 5 °C (41 °F) is some ten degrees lower than in cities on the French Riviera on a similar coastal latitude on the other side of Eurasia. Winters in particular are around 20 °C (36 °F) colder than on the mildest coastlines this far north
column7: and are considerably colder than locations on the North American east coast at similar latitudes such as Halifax
column8: Nova Scotia and Portland
column9: Maine.

column2: temperatures can drop below −20 °C (−4 °F) while mild spells of weather can raise daytime temperatures above freezing. The average monthly precipitation
column3: mainly in the form of snow
column4: is around 18.5 millimeters (0.73 in) from December to March. Snow is common during winter
column5: but individual snowfalls are light
column6: with a maximum snow depth of only 5 centimeters (2.0 in) in January. During winter
column7: clear sunny days are common.

column2: humid and rainy
column3: due to the East Asian monsoon. The warmest month is August
column4: with an average temperature of +19.8 °C (67.6 °F). Vladivostok receives most of its precipitation during the summer months
column5: and most summer days see some rainfall. Cloudy days are fairly common and because of the frequent rainfall
column6: humidity is high
column7: on average about 90% from June to August.

column2: Vladivostok receives 840 millimeters (33 in) per year
column3: but the driest year was 1943
column4: when 418 millimeters (16.5 in) of precipitation fell
column5: and the wettest was 1974
column6: with 1
column7: 272 millimeters (50.1 in) of precipitation. The winter months from December to March are dry
column8: and in some years they have seen no measurable precipitation at all. Extremes range from −31.4 °C (−24.5 °F) in January 1931 to +33.6 °C (92.5 °F) in July 1939.

column1: Head of the city of Vladivostok on the principles of unity of command directs the administration of the city of Vladivostok in accordance with federal laws

column1: The development and organization of the concepts

column1: Development of the draft budget of the city;
Control the use of territory and infrastructure of the city;

column4: at the end of 2018 amounted to 21.2 million tons.In 2015

column8: Vladivostok serves as the main starting point for the Trans-Siberian portion of the Eurasian Land Bridge.Vladivostok is the main air hub in the Russian Far East. Vladivostok International Airport (VVO) is the home base of Aurora

The Vladivostok International Airport was significantly upgraded in 2013 with a new 3500-metre runway capable of accommodating all aircraft types without any restrictions. The Terminal A was built in 2012 with a capacity of 3.5 million passengers per year.

column2: there operate nineteen radio stations

column4: 7 MHz

column6: oldies and music of 1980s-1990s. Radio Lemma (FM 102

column12: from 12 to 14 and from 18 to 19 on weekdays on the frequency of Radio Rossii (Radio of Russia).

column2: named after the Russian author Maxim Gorky
column3: was founded in 1931 and is used for drama

column2: a granite statue of the actor Yul Brynner (1920–1985) was inaugurated in Yul Brynner Park
column3: directly in front of the house where he was born at 15 Aleutskaya St.

column2: opened in 1890
column3: is the main museum of Primorsky Krai. Besides the main facility
column4: it has three branches in Vladivostok itself (including Arsenyev's Memorial House)
column5: and five branches elsewhere in the state. Among the items in the museum's collection are the famous 15th-century Yongning Temple Steles from the lower Amur.

column1: There are five professional theaters in the city. In 2014
column2: they were visited by 369.8 thousand spectators. The Primorsky Regional Academic Drama Theater named after Maxim Gorky is the oldest state theater in Vladivostok
column3: opened on November 3
column4: 1932. The theater employs 202 people: 41 actors (of them - three folk and nine honored artists of Russia).The Primorsky Pushkin Theater was built in 1907–1908
column5: and is currently one of the main cultural centers of the city. In the 1930s-40s
column6: the following still operating ones were successively opened: the Drama Theater of the Pacific Fleet
column7: the Primorsky Regional Puppet Theater
column8: and the Primorsky Regional Drama Theater of Youth. The regional puppet theater gave 484 performances in 2015
column9: which were attended by more than 52 thousand spectators. There are 500 puppets in the theater
column10: where 15 artists work. The troupe regularly goes on tour from Europe to Asia.The musical theater in Vladivostok is represented by the Primorsky Regional Philharmonic Society
column11: the largest concert organization in Primorsky Krai. The Philharmonic has organized the Pacific Symphony Orchestra and the Governor's Brass Orchestra. In 2013
column12: the Primorsky Opera and Ballet Theater was opened. On January 1
column13: 2016 it was transformed into a branch of the Mariinsky Theatre.

column1: The active development of art museums in Vladivostok began in the 1950s. In 1960
column2: the House of Artists was built
column3: in which there were exhibition halls. In 1965
column4: the Primorsky State Art Gallery was separated into a separate institution
column5: and later
column6: on the basis of its collection
column7: the Children's Art Gallery was created. In Soviet times
column8: one of the largest areas for exhibitions in Vladivostok was the exhibition hall of the Primorsky branch of the Union of Artists of Soviet Russia. In 1989 the gallery of contemporary art "Artetage" was opened.In 1995
column9: the Arka gallery of contemporary art was opened
column10: the first exposition of which consisted of 100 paintings donated by the collector Alexander Glezer. The gallery participates in international exhibitions and fairs. In 2005
column11: a non-commercial private gallery "Roytau" appeared. In recent years
column12: the centers of contemporary art "Salt" (created on the basis of the FEFU art museum) and "Zarya"

column2: 21 cinemas operated in Vladivostok
column3: and the total number of movie screenings was 1 million 501 thousand.

column1: Most of the city's cinemas - Ocean
column2: Galaktika
column3: Moscow (formerly called New Wave Cinema)
column4: Neptune 3D (formerly called Neptune and Borodino)
column5: Illusion
column6: Vladivostok - are renovated cinemas built in the Soviet years. Among them stands out "Ocean" with the largest (22 by 10 meters) screen in the Far East of the country
column7: located in the center of the city in the area of Sports Harbor. Together with the cinema "Ussuri"
column8: it is the venue for the annual international film festival "Pacific Meridians" (since 2002). Since December 10
column9: 2014 the IMAX 3D hall has been operating in the Ocean cinema.

column1: The city is home to the Vladivostok Pops Orchestra.
Russian rock band Mumiy Troll hails from Vladivostok and frequently puts on shows there. In addition
column2: the city hosted the "VladiROCKstok" International Music Festival in September 1996. Hosted by the mayor and governor
column3: and organized by two young American expatriates
column4: the festival drew nearly 10
column5: 000 people and top-tier musical acts from St. Petersburg (Akvarium and DDT) and Seattle (Supersuckers
column6: Goodness)
column7: as well as several leading local bands.Nowadays there is another annual music festival in Vladivostok
column8: Vladivostok Rocks International Music Festival and Conference (V-ROX). Vladivostok Rocks is a three-day open-air city festival and international conference for the music industry and contemporary cultural management. It offers the opportunity for aspiring artists and producers to gain exposure to new audiences and leading international professionals.The Russian Opera House houses the State Primorsky Opera and Ballet Theater.

column1: Pokrovskiy Park was once a cemetery. Converted into a park in 1934 but was closed in 1990.  Since 1990 the land the park sits on belongs to the Russian Orthodox Church.  During the rebuilding of the Orthodox Church
column2: graves were found.

column1: Minny Gorodok is a 91-acre (37 ha) public park. Minny Gorodok means "Mine Borough Park" in English. The park is a former military base that was founded in 1880. The military base was used for storing mines in underground storage. Converted into a park in 1985
column2: Minny Gorodok contains several lakes
column3: ponds
column4: and an ice-skating rink.

column1: Detsky Razvlekatelny Park is a children's amusement park located near the centre of the city.  The park contains a carousel
column2: gaming machines
column3: a Ferris wheel
column4: cafés
column5: an aquarium
column6: cinema
column7: and a stadium.

column1: Admiralsky Skver is a landmark located near the city's centre.  The Square is an open space
column2: dominated by the Triumfalnaya Arka. South of the square sits a museum of Soviet submarine S-56.

column1: Vladivostok is home to the football club FC Luch-Energiya Vladivostok
column2: who plays in the Russian First Division
column3: ice hockey club Admiral Vladivostok from the Kontinental Hockey League's Chernyshev Division
column4: and basketball club Spartak Primorye
column5: who plays in the Russian Basketball Super League.

column1: Local ecologists from the Ecocenter organization have claimed that much of Vladivostok's suburbs are polluted and that living in them can be classified as a health hazard. The pollution has a number of causes
column2: according to Ecocenter geo-chemical expert Sergey Shlykov. Vladivostok has about eighty industrial sites
column3: which may not be many compared to Russia's most industrialized areas
column4: but those around the city are particularly environmentally unfriendly
column5: such as shipbuilding and repairing
column6: power stations
column7: printing
column8: fur farming
column9: and mining.

column2: Vladivostok has a particularly vulnerable geography which compounds the effect of pollution. Winds cannot clear pollution from some of the most densely populated areas around the Pervaya and Vtoraya Rechka as they sit in basins which the winds blow over. In addition
column3: there is little snow in winter and no leaves or grass to catch the dust to make it settle down.

column2: arches with the names of each of Vladivostok's twin towns were placed in a park within the city.From Vladivostok ferry port next to the train station
column3: a ferry of the DBS Cruise Ferry travels regularly to Donghae
column4: South Korea and from there to Sakaiminato on the Japanese main island of Honshu.
